best-practice.name: unique titles
best-practice.rule: Each page title should be unique across the site.

best-practice.name: one and only one title
best-practice.rule: The page should contain exactly one title element.

best-practice.name: h1 substring of title
best-practice.rule: The text content of each h1 element should match all or part of the title content.

best-practice.name: navigation bars and menus
best-practice.rule: Each ol or ul element that appears to be a navigation bar or menu should be immediately preceded by a header element (h2..h6).
best-practice.info: FAE considers a list of links to be a navigation bar or menu. A list of links is defined as an ol or ul element where each li element (with one exception allowed) has as its sole content either a single text link (a element) or a nested list of links.

best-practice.name: redundant text links for area elements
best-practice.rule: Each area element should have a redundant text link (a element) with matching href value.

best-practice.name: use of heading elements
best-practice.rule: Heading elements (h1..h6) should be used for structuring information on the page.

best-practice.name: one or two h1 elements
best-practice.rule: The page should contain at least one and no more than two h1 elements.

best-practice.name: proper nesting of heading elements
best-practice.rule: Heading elements that follow the last h1 should be properly nested.
best-practice.info: Heading elements should be used without skipping levels when descending the hierarchy that starts with h1 and continues through h6. For example, an h3 element should follow an h2 element, whereas an h4 (or h5 or h6) should not. Note that this rule does not apply when ascending the hierarchy (for example, an h2 element may follow an h4 element).

best-practice.name: header content density
best-practice.rule: The text content contained in header elements (h1..h6) should range between 1 and 20 percent, inclusive, and not exceed 50 percent of the total text content of the page.

best-practice.name: form control labels
best-practice.rule: Each form control should be associated with a label element, either through encapsulation or id reference.
best-practice.info: Encapsulation simply means nesting the form control element within a label element. Reference is implemented by setting the label element's for attribute value equal to that of the form control's id attribute. Form controls tested include textarea and select elements, and input elements with type attribute values of text, password, checkbox, radio, file and image.

best-practice.name: nested tables
best-practice.rule: Deeply nested tables can cause problems when a document is rendered in a linear mode, e.g., by screen readers.

best-practice.name: data tables
best-practice.rule: Data tables should utilize thead and/or th elements.
best-practice.info: A table is considered to be a data table if it has two or more rows or columns and includes one or more thead or th elements.

best-practice.name: frame titles
best-practice.rule: Each frame element should have a title attribute.

best-practice.name: accesskey 1
best-practice.rule: When accesskey 1 is defined, it should provide access to the main content on the page.

best-practice.name: accesskey 2
best-practice.rule: When accesskey 2 is defined, it should provide access to the search function on the page.

best-practice.name: accesskey 3
best-practice.rule: When accesskey 3 is defined, it should provide access to the main menu on the page.

best-practice.name: images with alt attribute
best-practice.rule: Each img element should have an alt attribute.

best-practice.name: images with alt text
best-practice.rule: Each img element with an alt attribute should have alt text.

best-practice.name: embed elements
best-practice.rule: Each embed element should have alt text.

best-practice.name: applet elements
best-practice.rule: Each applet element should have alt text.

best-practice.name: object elements
best-practice.rule: Each object element should contain alternate text content.

best-practice.name: onmouseover and onfocus actions
best-practice.rule: Each element with an onmouseover attribute should also have an onfocus attribute, and their associated event handlers should trigger the same or similar actions.

best-practice.name: onmouseout and onblur actions
best-practice.rule: Each element with an onmouseout attribute should also have an onblur attribute, and their associated event handlers should trigger the same or similar actions.

best-practice.name: inline style elements
best-practice.rule: Avoid the use of inline style elements; use CSS instead.
best-practice.info: FAE currently tests for the following inline style elements: b, basefont, blink, center, font, i, marquee, strike and u.

best-practice.name: inline style attributes
best-practice.rule: Avoid using the deprecated color attribute on HTML elements for specifying color; use CSS instead.

best-practice.name: tables for positioning & layout
best-practice.rule: Avoid using tables for page layout; use CSS instead.
best-practice.info: The existence of deeply nested tables suggests that tables are being used for page layout. Nested tables can cause readability problems when a page is linearized.

best-practice.name: images with alt text
best-practice.rule: Each img element should have alt text.
best-practice.info: img elements with alt="" should be moved to CSS.

best-practice.name: decorative images
best-practice.rule: Avoid using img elements for stylistic purposes such as separator bars or list bullets; use CSS instead.

best-practice.name: DOCTYPE declaration
best-practice.rule: Each page should include a DOCTYPE declaration to facilitate validation.

best-practice.name: default language decl.
best-practice.rule: Each page should specify the default language using the lang and/or xml:lang attribute on the html element.
best-practice.info: For example, to specify English as the default language in HTML 4.0, use: <html lang="en"> and in XHTML, use: <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en">

best-practice.name: character encoding decl.
best-practice.rule: Each page should specify the character encoding with an html/head/meta element using the content attribute in conjunction with the http-equiv="content-type" attribute.
best-practice.info: For example, if the character encoding is UTF-8, it could be specified in XHTML with: <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
